educational_objective: Test for HIV in an adult patient with herpes zoster and unknown HIV status.
question_text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a 2-day history of a painful rash on the right side of his chest. He had chickenpox as a child. He takes no medications.On physical examination, vital signs are normal. He is oriented and in no acute distress. A vesicular rash over the right T4 dermatome is observed.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most appropriate serologic test to perform next?

options.text: Herpes simplex virus IgM and IgG

critique: The most appropriate serologic test to perform next in this patient is HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay (Option B). The patient has a classic dermatomal vesicular rash indicative of varicella-zoster virus (VZV). VZV is transmitted by inhalation and colonization of the respiratory tract, with subsequent viremic dissemination to skin, liver, spleen, and sensory ganglia (varicella). VZV establishes latency in the ganglia and can later reactivate, causing herpes zoster (shingles), especially in adults older than 60 years or immunosuppressed patients, such as those with HIV infection. Zoster is a disease of reactivation; patients have previously experienced VZV infection in the form of chickenpox. Zoster is less common in younger patients; however, HIV infection can predispose young patients to herpes zoster. As such, any young person who is diagnosed with shingles should undergo HIV testing.Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) infection is transmitted by oral-oral or oral-genital contact. HSV-1 is a common infection that typically causes gingivostomatitis in primary infection and herpes labialis with reactivation. Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) is sexually transmitted and typically causes genital and rectal ulcers. HSV-1 and HSV-2 typically do not cause dermatomal vesicular rashes. Because this patient's symptoms are not consistent with HSV infection, serologic testing for HSV IgM and IgG is not appropriate (Option A).VZV IgM and IgG testing (Option C) is not appropriate in this patient. Most persons have been exposed to VZV, and a positive IgG serologic result does not aid in the diagnosis of herpes zoster. Obtaining a VZV IgM level during a suspected episode of shingles is also not indicated because shingles is a reactivation of a previous VZV infection; therefore, a positive VZV IgM level would not be expected. Shingles is usually diagnosed clinically; if confirmation is needed, VZV polymerase chain reaction testing of a lesion can be performed.In an adult older than 60 years, shingles can be diagnosed clinically without the need for additional zoster testing (Option D). However, in younger patients, it would be inappropriate not to perform HIV testing.
key_points: Varicella-zoster virus establishes latency in the ganglia and can later reactivate, causing herpes zoster (shingles), especially in adults older than 60 years or immunosuppressed patients.
Younger patients diagnosed with shingles should undergo HIV testing.
references: Marra F, Parhar K, Huang B, et al. Risk factors for herpes zoster infection: A meta-analysis. Open Forum Infect Dis. 2020;7:ofaa005. PMID: 32010734 doi:10.1093/ofid/ofaa005
